deliberation: Verse 1 is purely historical prose describing succession and political installation of Zedekiah by Nebuchadnezzar. No metaphorical verbs or idiomatic phrases beyond standard royal language; all elements (becoming king, setting up a king, land of Judah) are literal.

The verse narrates refusal to listen to YHWH's words. The collocation 'שמע אל דברי' (to listen to the words) can, in some contexts, shade into 'obey', but here it functions as normal Hebrew for heeding speech; no special figurative image is foregrounded.

The actions of sending messengers and the request 'התפלל־נא בעדנו אל־יְהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵינוּ' are straightforward. 'Pray on our behalf' is literal intercession language, not an idiomatic metaphor in Hebrew here. No similes, metaphors, or hyperbole are present.
The statement that Jeremiah went in and out among the people and had not yet been put in prison is spatial and legal description. No figurative use of motion, no idiom beyond normal prose.

Military movements (Pharaoh's army going out, Chaldeans lifting the siege) are described in literal terms. The verbs 'יצא', 'שמע', 'ויעלו מעל' are used in their normal senses in a siege context; no metaphor or idiomatic expression dominates.

The prophetic formula 'ויהי דבר־יְהֹוָה אל־יִרְמְיָהוּ' depicts the 'word' as something that 'comes' to Jeremiah. This conventional formula personifies or reifies the divine word as an entity that moves from God to the prophet.

religious-discourse convention
instances.explanation: The 'word of YHWH' is personified as an entity that can 'come' to the prophet, turning an abstract communication into a quasi-agent that moves from God to Jeremiah.

deliberation: The verse delivers a divine oracle in plain predictive prose: the army of Pharaoh will return to Egypt. The verbs 'יוצא', 'שב' are literal movements of troops. No metaphor, simile, or idiom stands out as figurative beyond normal military language.

The Chaldeans 'will fight', 'capture' the city, and 'burn it with fire'. In the historical-prophetic context of siege and destruction this is straightforward literal prediction of conquest and burning, not a symbolic or metaphorical burning.

The key phrase 'אַל־תַּשִּׁ֤אוּ נַפְשֹֽׁתֵיכֶם֙' literally 'do not lift up your souls' is used idiomatically for self-delusion or self-encouragement with false hope. This is a conventional idiom which draws on a metaphor of 'lifting' the inner self but functions as a set expression.

instances.explanation: The idiom 'lift up your souls' uses a spatial image for an inner state of self-encouragement or delusion; here it warns them not to raise their inner expectations with the claim that the Chaldeans will depart.

deliberation: The conditional scenario that even if all the Chaldean army were struck down and only pierced, wounded men in their tents remained, they would still rise and burn the city functions as deliberate exaggeration to stress the inevitability of Jerusalem’s fall.

deliberation: The clause reports the army lifting the siege because of Pharaoh’s army. The verbs and prepositions describe literal military repositioning; there is no idiomatic or metaphorical extension beyond normal siege terminology.

Jeremiah’s leaving Jerusalem to go to Benjamin to divide property is straightforward narrative. The verb 'לחליק' here means to receive/share a portion; this is a normal juridical term, not a metaphor in this context.

The key expression is Irijah’s accusation 'אֶל־הַכַּשְׂדִּים אַתָּה נֹפֵל' literally 'you are falling to the Chaldeans'. Here 'to fall to' is idiomatic for 'defect/go over to' the enemy, not physical falling.

deliberation: Jeremiah denies the same accusation using the same verb: 'אינני נפל על־הכשדים'. Again 'fall upon/to the Chaldeans' is an idiomatic way to say 'defect', not literal falling.

deliberation: The verse reports anger, beating, and incarceration in a house that had been turned into a jail. These are literal descriptions; 'קצף' (to be furious) can be vivid but here functions as normal emotional vocabulary, not an extended metaphor.

Jeremiah’s coming to 'בית הבור' and 'החנֻיות' (the pit/dungeon and the cells) is a spatial-architectural description of confinement. Though 'בור' can metaphorically denote death or Sheol elsewhere, here it designates an actual dungeon; the usage is concrete.

Two expressions stand out: 'יש דבר מאת יְהֹוָה' and 'ביד מלך־בבל תינתן'. The first is simply 'is there a word/message from YHWH?', but the second uses 'hand' metaphorically for power: being 'given into the hand' means coming under the control of the king of Babylon.

instances.explanation: The phrase 'given into the hand' uses the hand as a metaphor for power and control, depicting Zedekiah as an object placed into the Babylonian king’s grasp.

deliberation: Jeremiah’s question about what sin he has committed and why he has been put in prison is straightforward legal/moral language. No figurative idioms beyond normal juridical verbs ('חטא', 'נתתם אותי אל בית הכלא') are employed.

The verse recalls the failed prediction of other prophets. 'לא יבוא מלך־בבל עליכם' is a literal claim about military action. The rhetorical question 'ואיה נביאיכם' is pointed but not figurative in form.

The request 'תִּפׇּל־נָ֤א תְחִנָּתִי֙ לְפָנֶ֔יךָ' literally 'may my supplication fall before you' is an idiom/metaphorical expression for presenting a plea in humility, picturing the petition as something that falls prostrate before the king.

deliberation: The verse describes Zedekiah’s command to keep Jeremiah in the court of the guard and to give him daily bread until the bread in the city was gone. These are literal provisions; 'עד תם כל־הלחם מן־העיר' is a chronological limit, not figurative.
